text:
This isn't strictly content related, but I could use some advice! I'm more than likely overthinking this, but...

I was contacted last month about a job opening in my area at a large company in the manufacturing industry. The position is for a content marketing manager who would manage a copywriter, help with strategy to some extent, and do copywriting the rest of the time (from what I can tell). I told the recruiter that I am really looking for remote positions or to go full time freelance in the next couple of months, but he said to just give it a try and see what happens.

He called me yesterday and said they are about to send the offer letter, and it will be 30-40% what I'm making at my current job :astonished:.

This is exciting, but I'm also torn. I really was hoping my next move would be to a remote position or freelance FT, and the position itself sounds a little boring, but the offer is one I can't take lightly. I'm in the interview process with a remote startup that would offer slightly more than I'm making now, but the position sounds more exciting than the job that pays more. I let them know that I'd be receiving an offer in the next day or so from the other company (they told me to tell them if/when I did), but they said I am the furthest along in the interview process and they need a few more days to interview the other candidates to make an informed decision.

I guess what I'm wondering is whether I should go with the high-paying job that might not be exactly what I want, or if I should hold out for a remote position (or to go FT freelance once my husband has insurance in a few months).

I was contacted last month about a job opening in my area at a large company in the manufacturing industry. The position is for a content marketing manager who would manage a copywriter, help with strategy to some extent, and do copywriting the rest of the time (from what I can tell). I told the recruiter that I am really looking for remote positions or to go full time freelance in the next couple of months, but he said to just give it a try and see what happens.

He called me yesterday and said they are about to send the offer letter, and it will be 30-40% what I'm making at my current job

.

This is exciting, but I'm also torn. I really was hoping my next move would be to a remote position or freelance FT, and the position itself sounds a little boring, but the offer is one I can't take lightly. I'm in the interview process with a remote startup that would offer slightly more than I'm making now, but the position sounds more exciting than the job that pays more. I let them know that I'd be receiving an offer in the next day or so from the other company (they told me to tell them if/when I did), but they said I am the furthest along in the interview process and they need a few more days to interview the other candidates to make an informed decision.

I guess what I'm wondering is whether I should go with the high-paying job that might not be exactly what I want, or if I should hold out for a remote position (or to go FT freelance once my husband has insurance in a few months).

text: I think it completely depends on your situation. Do you feel like you NEED a job right now and you want to keep gaining experience, or do you want to spend time looking for the perfect job? Do you have the luxury or a process to do the latter?

elements.text: I think it completely depends on your situation. Do you feel like you NEED a job right now and you want to keep gaining experience, or do you want to spend time looking for the perfect job? Do you have the luxury or a process to do the latter?

attachments.title: The Crossroads of Should and Must
attachments.text: This is a story about two roads — Should and Must. It’s a pep talk for anyone who’s chosen Should for far too long — months, years, maybe a

text:
First, if you want to talk actual numbers please feel free to email me at <mailto:janessalantz@gmail.com|janessalantz@gmail.com>. I'm a pretty decent negotiator and genuinely love working with people on things like this :slightly_smiling_face:

Second, I would look at the growth opportunities. A boring job with a lot of money is fine as long as there are people there you can still learn a lot from. What you don't want is to lock yourself into a career trajectory that stagnates. I was working with a friend on a problem very similar to this recently and he ended up taking the job that paid about $10k less, he made up that difference plus within 6 months because 1. he's really good at what he does 2. the company is growing.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: A company that isn't doing well financially, a bad manager, or a mediocre team can devastate your learning opportunities and that is never worth the tradeoff in $$ (unless for financial reasons you have to make that tradeoff, which is understandable and not something to feel guilty about. Put your time in, make the $$, and get out when you can)

text:
Three things that have helped me in career inflection points:

1- Becoming financially stable is a springboard to lots and lots of other things. I very much think it’s worth optimizing for money if you have obligations or debts that are impairing your career and creative freedoms. And it’s worth being very candid about that to yourself.

2 - Someone once explained to me that at every job you need to be “earning” or “learning” … ideally both but at least one.

3 - In this moment you may see this choice as binary. But there’s a third choice and that’s “use this as motivation to seek at many more options” Now that you know _someone_ in the market is will to pay you +40%, can you shop around and demand that elsewhere?

text:
It might just be a conversation to have with them. It's reasonable before you accept to ask what the opportunities for growth are.
• If I do really well in this role, what's the next step for me?
• Do you have a formalized career path rubric I could take a look at?
• Who are the most impactful employees at the company? What makes them so successful here?
This can help you suss out if it's a dead end or if there's room for learning (and another raise) in 2021.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text:
<@UJE5LQ2JC> That's a good point. I was thinking this morning about how I could potentially take this job (or one like it) to get to a more financially secure place and then consider going FT freelance in ~6 months. I'd really hate a leave a job so soon though.

<@UJG12DM1V> I asked the Marketing Director where he envisioned this position going/what growth would look like, and he said he really didn't know. The team was changing too quickly. That was a troubling answer for me.

text:
Yeah, you're right to see a red flag there.

Even in chaotic environments a good manager would be comfortable saying something like, "I'm committed to your career success, and while I can't guarantee any of this, here are some potential paths for this role..."

text: But again, I'm all for being mercenary--every company is, they will fire you as soon as you are no longer in their financial best interests. So if you want to try it out for 6-9 months, you shouldn't feel bad about it.
